list_page_teaser: The people who work for Al Swearengen at the Gem have well-defined roles - and personalities to match.  Click to see the images!
description_html:
Al Swearengen's team is rather like a family.

  • Dan Dority's image shows he is down-to-earth and logical — like a son to Al and a big brother to Johnny.
  • Johnny Burns's image shows he is friendly, and open to learning from Dan — like a little brother.
  • Silas Adams's image shows he is decisive and has a head for strategies — rather like Al's brother, and an uncle to Dan and Johnny.
  • Trixie's image shows she is passionate and open to new experiences.

Everyone on Al Swearengen's crew respects and admires Al, and his image shows he is good at formulating strategies that can help his businesses succeed.
story_html:
Writing really good stories explaining how the spiritual portraits of fictional characters reflect the characters' personalities is time-consuming. I'd rather just turn out images and let people figure them out on their own.

The Deadwood Experiment

In building a site like this, the following questions come to mind:

  1. Are the explanatory stories provided necessary or even helpful?
  2. Can fans of a show with an ensemble cast appreciate the images — and see the relationships between the characters — without explanatory stories?
  3. Would it be better — maybe in some cases, at least — to write a single article about all of the portraits in a single show, and post it on social media? This could certainly be easier and might even be more informative than writing a separate story for each character.

For the time being, these spiritual portraits of Deadwood characters are presented without stories. If you are familiar with the show and know a bit about Jungian Psychological Types, you should be able to see how the characters with similar temperaments have similar portraits.

Keep Up-to-Date!

If you're interested in learning when we write new stories and post new images, follow this site on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

image_list.title: Dan Dority
image_list.subtitle_html: Al Swearengen's Bodyguard, Enforcer, and Hit Man
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Dan Dority's spiritual portrait shows he is down-to-earth (Yellow) and objective and impersonal (Green).  Because he is bigger and older and even more decisive than Johnny, Dan is like his older big brother.  Click on the image to see a full-size version!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Dan Dority's dominant personality trait, his pragmatism.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Dan demonstrates this trait in the way he helps Al with tactics, often serving as a hit-man, while taking little interest in helping Al strategize.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Dan Dority's auxiliary personality trait, his objectivity.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Dan demonstrates this trait in the way he keeps his cool and does not let his emotions get the best of him.

image_list.title: Johnny Burns
image_list.subtitle_html: Bartender and Disposer of Corpses
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Johnny Burns' spiritual portrait shows he is very open to new experiences (Yellow) and a bit more emotional (Red) than Dan and Adam.  Because he is smaller and younger and less cold-blooded than Dan, he looks up to Dan as he might look up to an older big brother.  Click on the image to see a full-size version!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Johnny Burns' dominant personality trait, his strong preference for being realistic.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Johnny demonstrates this trait in the way his is very practical and down-to-earth.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Johnny Burns' auxiliary personality trait, his preference for emotion over reason.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Johnny demonstrates this trait when he is unable to kill the innocent prostitute Jen, due to his feelings for her.

image_list.title: Silas Adams
image_list.subtitle_html: Bagman from Yankton
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Silas Adams' spiritual portrait shows he prefers ideas (Blue) to facts, which means he has a head for strategies.  He also has the logical decisiveness (Green) needed to carry out cold-blooded acts.  Click on the image to see a full-size version!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Silas Adams' dominant personality trait, his moderate preference for ideas over facts.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  Silas demonstrates this when he and Al discuss strategies in dealing with government officials and the like.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Silas Adams' auxiliary personality trait, his very strong preference for reason over emotion.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  Silas demonstrates this trait in the way he is always calm and composed and rarely shows any emotion.

image_list.title: Trixie
image_list.subtitle_html: Prostitute at the Gem
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Trixie is extremely perceptive and open to new experiences (Yellow), and has a very slight preference for making emotional (Red) rather than logical decisions.  Click on the image to see a full-size version!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Trixie's dominant personality trait, her openness to new experiences.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Trixie demonstrates this trait in the way she is willing to try out a number of different occupations in various businesses in the town.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Trixie's auxiliary personality trait, her warmth and passion.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Trixie demonstrates this preference in the way she obviously continues to have deep feelings for Al even when she has stopped working for him and moved on to other opportunities for employment.

image_list.title: Al Swearengen
image_list.subtitle_html: Owner of the Gem Theater
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Al Swearengen's spiritual portrait shows he is logical (Green) and comfortable with theories and abstractions (Blue). Click on the image to see a full-size version!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Al Swearengen's dominant personality trait, a strong preference for ideas over facts.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Al demonstrates this trait in the way he deals with adversaries such as George Hearst, by focusing on figuring out what strategies to use before deciding on specific tactics.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Al Swearengen's auxiliary personality trait, his ability to stay cool and objective in times of stress.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Al demonstrates this trait when he insists on walking back to the Gem under his own power after Hearst cuts off his finger.
